refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Functions for working with font objects.

A font object represents a font face at a specific size and with certain other parameters (pixels-per-em, points-per-em, variation settings) specified. Font objects are created from font face objects, and are used as input to hb_shape(), among other things.

Client programs can optionally pass in their own functions that implement the basic, lower-level queries of font objects. This set of font functions is defined by the virtual methods in hb_font_funcs_t.
HarfBuzz provides a built-in set of lightweight default functions for each method in hb_font_funcs_t.

The default font functions are implemented in terms of the hb_font_funcs_t methods of the parent font object. This allows client programs to override only the methods they need to, and otherwise inherit the parent font's implementation, if any.

refsect2.title: hb_font_set_scale ()
refsect2.programlisting: void hb_font_set_scale (hb_font_t *font, int x_scale, int y_scale);
refsect2.para: Sets the horizontal and vertical scale of a font.

The font scale is a number related to, but not the same as, font size. Typically the client establishes a scale factor to be used between the two. For example, 64, or 256, which would be the fractional-precision part of the font scale. This is necessary because hb_position_t values are integer types and you need to leave room for fractional values in there.
For example, to set the font size to 20, with 64 levels of fractional precision you would call hb_font_set_scale(font, 20 * 64, 20 * 64).

In the example above, even what font size 20 means is up to you. It might be 20 pixels, or 20 points, or 20 millimeters. HarfBuzz does not care about that. You can set the point size of the font using hb_font_set_ptem(), and the pixel size using hb_font_set_ppem().
The choice of scale is yours but needs to be consistent between what you set here, and what you expect out of hb_position_t as well has draw / paint API output values.
Fonts default to a scale equal to the UPEM value of their face. A font with this setting is sometimes called an "unscaled" font.
Since: 0.9.2

refsect2.title: hb_font_set_synthetic_bold ()
refsect2.programlisting: void hb_font_set_synthetic_bold (hb_font_t *font, float x_embolden, float y_embolden, hb_bool_t in_place);
refsect2.para: Sets the "synthetic boldness" of a font.
Positive values for x_embolden / y_embolden make a font bolder, negative values thinner. Typical values are in the 0.01 to 0.05 range. The default value is zero.
Synthetic boldness is applied by offsetting the contour points of the glyph shape.
Synthetic boldness is applied when rendering a glyph via hb_font_draw_glyph().
If in_place is false, then glyph advance-widths are also adjusted, otherwise they are not. The in-place mode is useful for simulating font grading.
Since: 7.0.0

refsect2.title: hb_font_set_synthetic_slant ()
refsect2.para: Sets the "synthetic slant" of a font. By default is zero. Synthetic slant is the graphical skew applied to the font at rendering time.
HarfBuzz needs to know this value to adjust shaping results, metrics, and style values to match the slanted rendering.
refsect2.note: Note: The glyph shape fetched via the hb_font_draw_glyph() function is slanted to reflect this value as well.
Note: The slant value is a ratio. For example, a 20% slant would be represented as a 0.2 value.
refsect2.para: Since: 3.3.0

Note that this overrides all existing variations set on font . Axes not included in coords will be effectively set to their default values.
refsect2.note: Note: Coordinates should be normalized to 2.14.

entry.para: Array of variation coordinates to apply.

refsect2.para: Since: 1.4.2

refsect2.title: hb_font_get_var_coords_normalized ()
refsect2.para: Fetches the list of normalized variation coordinates currently set on a font.
Note that this returned array may only contain values for some (or none) of the axes; omitted axes effectively have zero values.
Return value is valid as long as variation coordinates of the font are not modified.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: coordinates array

refsect2.para: Since: 1.4.2

refsect2.title: hb_font_glyph_from_string ()
refsect2.para: Fetches the glyph ID from font that matches the specified string. Strings of the format gidDDD or uniUUUU are parsed automatically.
refsect2.note: Note: len == -1 means the string is null-terminated.

entry.para: The length of the string s
The glyph ID corresponding to the string requested.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: true if data found, false otherwise

refsect2.para: Since: 0.9.2

refsect2.title: hb_font_glyph_to_string ()
refsect2.programlisting: void hb_font_glyph_to_string (hb_font_t *font, hb_codepoint_t glyph, char *s, unsigned int size);
refsect2.para: Fetches the name of the specified glyph ID in font and returns it in string s .
If the glyph ID has no name in font , a string of the form gidDDD is generated, with DDD being the glyph ID.
According to the OpenType specification, glyph names are limited to 63 characters and can only contain (a subset of) ASCII.

entry.para: The string containing the glyph name.

refsect2.para: Since: 0.9.2

refsect2.title: hb_font_get_serial ()
refsect2.programlisting: unsigned int hb_font_get_serial (hb_font_t *font);
refsect2.para: Returns the internal serial number of the font. The serial number is increased every time a setting on the font is changed, using a setter function.

refsect2.title: hb_font_funcs_t
refsect2.programlisting: typedef struct hb_font_funcs_t hb_font_funcs_t;
refsect2.para: Data type containing a set of virtual methods used for working on hb_font_t font objects.

HarfBuzz provides a lightweight default function for each of
the methods in hb_font_funcs_t. Client programs can implement their own replacements for the individual font functions, as needed, and replace the default by calling the setter for a method.

refsect2.title: hb_font_extents_t
refsect2.para: Font-wide extent values, measured in font units.

Note that typically ascender is positive and descender
negative, in coordinate systems that grow up.

refsect2.title: hb_glyph_extents_t
refsect2.para: Glyph extent values, measured in font units.
Note that height is negative, in coordinate systems that grow up.

entry.para: Distance from the x-origin to the left extremum of the glyph.
Distance from the top extremum of the glyph to the y-origin.
Distance from the left extremum of the glyph to the right extremum.
